title-group.article-title: Role of Social Media Applications in Improving Sexual Health Awareness and Reducing the Incidence of Sexually Transmitted Diseases among Adults

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: In many communities across the globe, sexual health is a sensitive topic due to which people do not find it comfortable to talk or discuss openly about it. The objectives of the current article are to identify the role of social media in creating sexual health awareness, elaborate on the role of social media in influencing sexual health behaviors, identify the risk of misinformation and stigmatization, enumerate the potential challenges in using social media platforms to create awareness and propose measures to overcome these identified challenges. Under these circumstances, social media has emerged as a platform that provides instant access to sexual health resources, making it easier for adults to learn about sexual and reproductive health. Owing to the unregulated content being available across different social media applications, it is quite possible that these platforms can act as a medium to spread misinformation. In conclusion, social media applications have the potential to transform sexual health information and play a vital role in the prevention of sexually transmitted diseases. The need of the hour is to acknowledge their limitations and come out with comprehensive solutions to counter them and optimize the utility of social media platforms in empowering adults to make correct sexual health-related decisions.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Social media applications have emerged as one of the key sources of health-related information for youths and adults and play a defining role in determining their knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors.[1] This is mainly because these applications offer instant, peer-driven, and interactive educational content that resonates with adults, unlike traditional sources such as schools or healthcare professionals.[1] In fact, realizing the global reach of these applications (such as WhatsApp, Instagram, and YouTube) and the role these social media platforms can play in behavior modifications, policymakers and program managers have proposed leveraging them to increase awareness of different health issues, including sensitive topics such as reproductive health and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).[12] The objectives of the current article are to identify the role of social media in creating sexual health awareness, elaborate the role of social media in influencing sexual health behaviors, identify the risk of misinformation and stigmatization, enumerate the potential challenges in using social media platforms to create awareness and propose measures to overcome these identified challenges.

sec.title: SOCIAL MEDIA AND SEXUAL HEALTH AWARENESS
sec.p: In many communities across the globe, sexual health is a sensitive topic due to which people do not find it comfortable to talk or discuss openly about it.[3] Under these circumstances, social media has emerged as a platform that provides instant access to sexual health resources, making it easier for adults to learn about sexual and reproductive health.[4] The information is often available in adult-friendly formats (such as infographics, interactive posts, and videos), crucial for better engagement and simplifying complex topics.[5] These platforms allow peers to openly discuss different aspects of sexual health, which is essential to reducing stigma and fostering acceptance and awareness.[45] In addition, the information shared on these platforms can bridge the gap in traditional sex education and promote safe sex practices (such as regular condom use and testing for STDs).[45]

These platforms give a chance to adult to ask sensitive sexual health-related questions anonymously without the fear of being judged by their peers.[6] Different public health agencies are using social media to run awareness drives and reach a global audience as a part of the commemoration of World AIDS Day and STD prevention weeks.[7] Healthcare professionals can share their expertise to correct myths and misinformation about different STDs, thereby ensuring that adults receive accurate sexual health education and are empowered to make correct decisions.[456] At the same time, social media applications have also been used as a medium to encourage STD testing, undergo screening, receive vaccination, and seek expert advice by linking to consultation services.[5678]

sec.title: INFLUENCE OF SOCIAL MEDIA ON SEXUAL HEALTH BEHAVIORS
sec.p: Social media can influence the sexual health behaviors of adult in multiple ways, starting with changing their attitudes and practices toward safe sex practices by normalizing conversations about the use of condoms, testing for STDs, and practicing birth control measures.[69] It is not unusual for adult often practice their sexual health behaviors depending on what they see on different social media platforms, and this content can significantly change their opinion about casual relationships and contraception.[10] In fact, adult realizes the significance of consent, maintaining boundaries, being a part of healthy relationships, and understanding their rights and expectations in intimate settings.[910] The campaigns that are run across different social media platforms can encourage adults to take proactive steps toward improving their sexual health, such as regular STD screenings and HPV vaccination.[45]

More importantly, these platforms provide access to online sexual health resources, making it easier for adults to access professional guidance.[5] However, there are negative sides as well, wherein the available content encourages unprotected sex, multiple partners, or other risky behaviors, which can influence adults to make unsafe choices.[11] Moreover, myths about contraceptives, withdrawal methods of contraception, or symptoms of STDs can mislead adults, augmenting the risk of unintended pregnancies or infections.[11] In addition, unrealistic depictions of relationships on social media can remarkably impact the self-esteem of adults, leading to anxiety towards sexual experiences and choices.[69] In other words, social media can popularize both beneficial and harmful trends and influence the sexual behavior of adults.[711]

sec.title: SOCIAL MEDIA AND THE RISK OF MISINFORMATION AND STIGMATIZATION
sec.p: Due to the unregulated content available across social media platforms, these platforms can easily spread misinformation and encourage stigmatization.[6] This can be in the form of spreading false information like only high-risk people (viz., commercial sex workers) can acquire STD infections or home remedies can cure these infections.[12] Some of the viral trends and challenges can provoke adults to indulge in risky sexual behaviors or take unverified treatment, which can significantly improve the health risks among adults.[9] There is a definite possibility that people can make exaggerated claims about sexual health, which can create unnecessary panic and reinforce fear rather than promote informed decision-making.[911] Further, these platforms can be used to promote discrimination against adults diagnosed with STDs, which discourages them from seeking appropriate medical treatment.[6]

Reports have surfaced on social media, wherein misinformation about contraceptives (like contraceptive pills can cause infertility or condoms are ineffective) can result in the promotion of unsafe sexual practices and augmented health risks.[11] There are even incidents when some people without any medical expertise spread misleading information, which is often followed by adults instead of availing guidance from trained experts.[13] There have been incidents when discussions about sexual health on social media platforms received negative comments, which prevented adults from openly discussing the prevention and treatment of STDs.[1012] In continuation, there is a possibility that people who acquire STDs are often stigmatized and are regarded as a form of punishment on these platforms, and this significantly discourages people from availing of healthcare services.[6] Finally, it is important to understand that in the absence of consistent and prompt efforts to clarify myths and misinformation, it becomes extremely difficult to reverse their impact.[14]

sec.title: IDENTIFIED CHALLENGES AND POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS
sec.p: Multiple challenges have been identified about using social media platforms to create awareness about sexual health information, and these must be overcome to keep the adults well-informed and empowered with correct information.[512141516171819] The primary concern is the rapid spread of misinformation about STDs through viral posts,[12] and this will require establishing liaisons between these social media platforms and public health agencies to disseminate the right information and encouraging digital literacy among adults to critically analyze health content before sharing.[515] In addition, it is important to employ artificial intelligence-driven tools that can check and flag misleading health claims in real time.[16] The next biggest challenge is the lack of oversight on the content that is being shared on different social media applications.[14] This calls for the need to increase the extent of collaboration between such platforms and medical experts to ensure that sexual content is reviewed by professionals.[17] Other approaches will be to introduce some kind of verification badge for credible sexual health educators and organizations and introduce some form of penalty for people who regularly spread misinformation.[18]

The next challenge is the difficulty of identifying reliable sources, considering that multiple influencers and self-proclaimed health experts are present on these platforms.[15] This concern can be effectively dealt with by introducing digital health initiatives in schools to educate adults on how to differentiate between credible and unreliable sources, creating official health resource communities on social media, and linking users to verified agencies like the World Health Organization.[1518] Owing to the scientific algorithms, most educational posts about sexual health are flagged and this limits the reach of accurate information.[19] The desired approach will be to work with platform regulators to distinguish between harmful content and educational content.[19] Another strategy will be to come up with alternative methods like podcasts to promote a wide reach of correct information.[19] In the current era, social media platforms generally personalize content based on the preferences of users, which means that they might get only that information that aligns with their preexisting beliefs, including myths about STDs.[19] The potential solutions will be to promote exposure to different viewpoints by modifying social media algorithms and introducing interactive fact-checking features through which users can report and challenge misinformation.[14]

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Social media applications have the potential to transform sexual health information and play a vital role in the prevention of STDs. The need of the hour is to acknowledge their limitations and come out with comprehensive solutions to counter them and optimize the utility of social media platforms in empowering adults to make correct sexual health-related decisions.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.
